API Reference¶

This section provides API documentation for the main Momentum modules. All public classes and functions are listed below. For details, see the source code and docstrings.

Momentum - A minimal, one-task-at-a-time CLI tracker.

A command-line task management tool that enforces focus by allowing only one active task at a time. Features a persistent backlog, interactive prompts, and clean status displays with optional emoji/color output.

Usage:

python cli.py add “Task description” python cli.py done python cli.py backlog add “Future task” python cli.py status

momentum.cli.merge_and_dedup_case_insensitive(list1, list2)[source]¶

momentum.cli.safe_input(prompt, validator=None)[source]¶

Get user input with optional validation and Unicode safety.

Parameters:

  • prompt – The input prompt to display

  • validator – Optional function that takes input and returns (valid, error_msg)

Returns:

The validated input, or None if user cancels/validation fails

Return type:

str

momentum.cli.safe_int_input(prompt, min_val=None, max_val=None)[source]¶

Get integer input with validation and Unicode safety.

Parameters:

  • prompt – The input prompt to display

  • min_val – Minimum allowed value (inclusive)

  • max_val – Maximum allowed value (inclusive)

Returns:

The validated integer, or None if invalid/cancelled

Return type:

int or None

momentum.cli.migrate_task_data(data)[source]¶

Migrate all tasks in the data dict to ensure they have a ‘state’ field. Returns True if any migration was performed.

Return type:

bool

Parameters:

data (dict)

Load data from storage file, returning empty dict if file doesn’t exist.

Save data to storage file with UTF-8 encoding and error handling.

Return today’s date as a string in YYYY-MM-DD format.

momentum.cli.ensure_today(data)[source]¶

Ensure today’s date exists in data with proper structure and return today’s data.

Mark the current task as completed.

Handle user selection of next task after completing current one.

momentum.cli.parse_tags(task_text)[source]¶

Parse @categories and #tags from task text.

Parameters:

task_text (str) – The task description potentially containing tags

Returns:

(original_text, categories_list, tags_list)

Return type:

tuple

Examples

>>> parse_tags("Fix bug @work #urgent")
("Fix bug @work #urgent", ["work"], ["urgent"])

>>> parse_tags("Simple task")
("Simple task", [], [])
momentum.cli.validate_tag_format(tag)[source]¶

Validate if a tag follows the correct format.

Parameters:

tag (str) – The tag to validate (without @ or # prefix)

Returns:

True if valid, False otherwise

Return type:

bool

Valid format:

  • Only letters, numbers, underscores, hyphens

  • 1-50 characters long

  • No spaces or special characters

momentum.cli.format_task_with_tags(task_text, categories, tags, plain_mode=False)[source]¶

Format task text with highlighted categories and tags.

Parameters:

  • task_text (str) – The original task text

  • categories (List[str]) – List of categories found in the task

  • tags (List[str]) – List of tags found in the task

  • plain_mode (bool) – If True, don’t add color codes

Returns:

Formatted task text with highlighted tags

Return type:

str

momentum.cli.filter_tasks(tasks, filter_categories=None, filter_tags=None)[source]¶

Filter tasks by categories and/or tags.

Parameters:

  • tasks (List[dict]) – List of task dictionaries

  • filter_categories (Optional[List[str]]) – Categories to filter by (e.g., [“work”, “personal”])

  • filter_tags (Optional[List[str]]) – Tags to filter by (e.g., [“urgent”, “low”])

Return type:

List[dict]

Returns:

List of tasks matching the filters

momentum.cli.parse_filter_string(filter_str)[source]¶

Parse filter string into lists of categories and tags.

Parameters:

filter_str (str) – Comma-separated string like “@work,#urgent,@personal”

Returns:

(is_valid: bool, categories: List[str], tags: List[str], error_message: str)

Return type:

tuple

Examples

>>> parse_filter_string("@work,#urgent")
(True, ["work"], ["urgent"], "")

>>> parse_filter_string("@work, #urgent, @personal")  # spaces ok
(True, ["work", "personal"], ["urgent"], "")

>>> parse_filter_string("work,#urgent")
(False, [], ["urgent"], "Invalid filter item: 'work'. Must start with @ (category) or # (tag).")

>>> parse_filter_string("@,@work,oops,#tag1")
(False, ["work"], ["tag1"], "Invalid category format: '@'. Use letters, numbers, underscores, and hyphens only. Invalid filter item: 'oops'. Must start with @ (category) or # (tag).")

momentum.cli.prompt_next_action(data)[source]¶

Ask user what to do after completing a task.

Parameters:

data – The full data dictionary containing backlog

Returns:

(“pull”, None) to pull from backlog,

(“add”, str) to add the given task, (None, None) to skip

Return type:

tuple

momentum.cli.cmd_add(args)[source]¶

Add a new task or offer to add to backlog if active task exists.

momentum.cli.cmd_done(args)[source]¶

Complete the current active task and prompt for next action.

momentum.cli.cmd_status(args)[source]¶

Display current status showing completed tasks and active task.

momentum.cli.cmd_newday(args)[source]¶

Initialize a new day’s data structure.

momentum.cli.cmd_backlog(args)[source]¶

Handle backlog subcommands: add, list, pull, remove.

momentum.cli.cmd_cancel(args)[source]¶
momentum.cli.cmd_history(args)[source]¶

Show task history filtered by type (cancelled, archived, all).

momentum.cli.build_parser()[source]¶

Build and configure the argument parser for all CLI commands.

momentum.cli.main()[source]¶

Main entry point for the task tracker CLI.

Display utilities for Momentum.
